{{lowercase|title=e2fsprogs}} {{Infobox software | name = e2fsprogs | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | developer = [[Theodore Ts'o]] | latest release version = 1.41.14 | latest release date = {{release date and age|2010|12|22}} | latest preview version = 1.42-WIP-1016 | latest preview date = {{release date and age|2011|10|17}} | operating system = [[Unix-like]] | platform = | programming language = C | genre = [[File system]] utilities | license = [[GNU General Public License|GPL]] | website = http://e2fsprogs.sourceforge.net/ }} {{Portal|Free software}} '''e2fsprogs''' (sometimes called the '''e2fs programs''') is a set of utilities for maintaining the [[ext2]], [[ext3]] and [[ext4]] [[file system]]s. Since those file systems are often the default for [[Linux distribution]]s, it is commonly considered to be essential software.
Included with e2fsprogs are: * <tt>e2fsck</tt>, a [[fsck]] program that checks for and corrects inconsistencies * <tt>mke2fs</tt>, used for creating ext2, ext3 and ext4 file systems * <tt>resize2fs</tt>, which can expand and shrink ext2, ext3 and ext4 file systems * <tt>tune2fs</tt>, used to modify file system parameters * <tt>dumpe2fs</tt>, which prints superblock and block group information. * <tt>debugfs</tt>, used to manually view or modify internal structures of the file system
Many of these utilities are based on the <tt>libext2fs</tt> library.
Despite what its name might suggest, the e2fsprogs work not only with ext2 and ext3 but also with ext4. Although ext3's [[Journaling file system|journaling]] capability can reduce the need to use <tt>e2fsck</tt>, it is sometimes still necessary to help protect from kernel bugs or bad hardware.
[[File:E2fsck-uninit.svg|thumb|[[fsck]] time/Inode Count([[ext3]] vs. [[ext4]])]]
With ext4 the e2fsck runtime should come down considerably.
As the [[userspace]] companion for the ext2, ext3, and ext4 drivers in the [[Linux kernel]], the e2fsprogs are most commonly used with [[GNU]]/[[Linux]]. However, they have been ported to other systems, such as [[FreeBSD]] and [[Darwin (operating system)|Darwin]].
